newsitem.title: USA: U.S. blue chips extend slide, NYSE curbs set.
newsitem.headline: U.S. blue chips extend slide, NYSE curbs set.

text.p: U.S. stocks extended their morning slide on Friday, nearly reversing Thursday's rally to a record high, led down by Dow component Hewlett-Packard Co, which posted earnings below forecasts.
The New York Stock Exchange said it set curbs in index-arbitrage orders at 1038 EDT/1438 GMT after the Dow Jones industrial average fell 50 points, or 0.7 percent, to about 7282.
The Dow later slipped about 53 points to 7281. The Nasdaq composite was down eight to 1346.
Analysts said profit taking helped bring the market lower.

"It is giving back some of the profits from the last couple of weeks," said Frank Calta, a trader at Dain Bosworth. "We've had one heck of a run. A little profit taking is healthy. I don't see a sentiment change."

Hewlett-Packard also weighed down stocks after the company posted quarterly earnings $0.75 per share, below consensus estimates of $0.80 per share, after the market closed on Thursday. Hewlett-Packard fell 5-1/8 to 53-3/4.
Stocks felt the effect of Treasuries, where the long bond was off 12/32 to yield 6.90 percent after April housing starts and University of Michigan consumer sentiment data.
